text:
Councillors decide whether to back £8m Exeter pool and bus station project overspend - live updates By Alex_Richards | Posted: July 11, 2017 2 COMMENTS SHARES Comments (2) 
The council's Executive Committee is about to decide whether they back the a controversial uplift in the cost of Exeter's major St Sidwell's Point and bus station project. 
Of three choices on the table (laid out in detail in our live blog below) , the one the city council has recommended moving forward with requires an extra £8m - bringing the overall project cost to nearly £40m. 
Return to Devon Live home page or scroll down for our live coverage 
The options were revealed on Saturday, July 1 and most of the cash overspend would be borrowed from the Government. 
The council say a variety of factors are to blame for the cost rising far past the original estimates, but that it is mainly the fallout of the Brexit. 
The developments, funded by Labour-led Exeter City Council, are seen as crucial to the overall £115m redevelopment in partnership with the Crown Estate. 
But Conservative Party opposition in the city say they are "flabbergasted" that it has reached this point. 
Following a Leisure Complex and Bus Station Programme Board on Monday, the city council's Executive are meeting tonight and will be asked to give the recommendation their backing. 
Whatever decision is made tonight, it will gain its approval at a meeting of the full council at Exeter Guildhall on Wednesday, July 19.
